title: Sarah Jessica Parker Uses Google‚Äôs Try-On Feature ‚Äî So I Had To Try It
text:
Sarah Jessica Parker Uses Google‚Äôs Try-On Feature ‚Äî So I Had To Try It

While we all may have very clear visions of Carrie Bradshaw running around Manhattan in Manolo Blahnik heels and spending hours playing dress up in luxury stores, the real life style icon Sarah Jessica Parker, today, is opting for quick and efficient online shopping with the help of Google.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt consider myself a very good shopper because I‚Äôm seduced by imagery and what looks great on somebody else. But there‚Äôs a truth about my size and what colors look good on me,‚Äù Parker exclusively tells Refinery29. And thanks to Google‚Äôs ‚ÄúTry On‚Äù feature, Parker can actually envision herself in pieces before hastily carting them up. ‚ÄúI think this is one use of [AI] that feels not only benign, but potentially quite helpful. It creates clarity about how things may or may not look on you.‚Äù

While I‚Äôm personally quite weary of AI in general, as I was speaking to SJP, I knew I had to try this feature for myself. Because although I wax poetic about all the best fashion to shop online, I find myself gravitating more towards in-person shopping because I‚Äôm unsure how many pieces will fit my petite-yet-curvy body. With that, I used some of SJP‚Äôs best holiday season dressing advice to see how her favorite styles actually look on myself through Google Try On.

The technology came out earlier this year, but it‚Äôs just gotten a refresh with SJP‚Äôs new holiday campaign. According to Google‚Äôs blog, the virtual try-on technology allows ‚Äúshoppers to try on billions of items of clothing from our Shopping Graph. It‚Äôs powered by a new custom image generation model for fashion, which understands the human body and nuances of clothing ‚Äî like how different materials fold, stretch and drape on different bodies.‚Äù

Again, I was skeptical but excited at the same time.

Self-declared ‚Äúlousy shopper‚Äù Parker explains: ‚ÄúI just think it‚Äôs really helpful and really user-friendly, and I‚Äôm hoping it kind of cuts out some of the chaos and hysteria around shopping,‚Äù adding: ‚ÄúI think this idea of Google Shopping with the ability to actually see it on your person takes some of that intimidation away, but also you feel more assured that you‚Äôre purchasing something that will likely really suit the occasion and your person.‚Äù

It works by searching for fashion items on Google and clicking into a product suggestion before seeing a ‚Äútry it on‚Äù pop-up button. Then you can upload a full-body image of yourself and the AI technology realistically adds the clothing onto your body. It also has a follow-up feature where you can save and send the image to your group chat if you need a second opinion. (And if you‚Äôre wondering, SJP says she would definitely text looks to longtime collaborator and Sex and the City costume designer Molly Rogers for fashion help).

As SJP went on listing her favorite festive attire ‚Äî from houndstooth and platinum to ‚Äúchiffon big skirts from the eighties with a leotard‚Äù (√† la Carrie Bradshaw) and jewel-tone tights paired with patent leather Mary Janes ‚Äî I put some to the test with Google Try On.

After uploading a couple of full-body photos of myself wearing fitting clothing as suggested on my phone, one photo worked best and saved into Google so it could be reused for every new product I selected. (I think in the future I‚Äôd opt for a tank top and biker shorts for the most accurate depiction of my body, especially for skin-baring pieces, but I was pleased with how Google auto-generated my body, especially in mini dresses (see below).

‚ÄúI went to a party the other evening and the host was wearing a pinstripe suit, but the pinstripes were all sparkly, and I loved it,‚Äù Parker says. And so I searched for just that and clicked on a suit from Sandro via Nordstrom, which I could see myself standing in within 10 seconds. (It‚Äôs important to note that the feature doesn‚Äôt work on the first sponsored products that pop up on the search page, and not every single retailer offers it.)

I also wanted to virtually try on a vintage-inspired party dress after Parker declared: ‚ÄúI personally love plaids and tartans this time of year. It‚Äôs really old fashioned, but I see more and more of it and it‚Äôs really exciting.‚Äù Eager to try a Free People dress with a drop waist and bubble skirt (both trendy yet polarizing silhouettes), I was pleasantly surprised by how it looked on my body.¬†The feature even styled me in the same shoes that the model is wearing.

And when she isn‚Äôt attending lavish soirees, SJP is opting for humble winter wardrobe staples. ‚ÄúMy day-to-day, I‚Äôm in waffle-cotton Hanes men‚Äô s leggings in white. And I‚Äôm in 20-year-old cashmere cardigans from J. Crew.‚Äù

I‚Äôll spare you the unflattering image of me wearing Hanes‚Äô men‚Äôs leggings. But hey, thankfully I could try them virtually before assuming just because SJP loves them that they‚Äôd also look good on me, and wasting my time and money! But it was fun playing around with how more practical cardigans ‚Äî as well as more elaborate styles, like gowns that I may never actually wear ‚Äî looked like.¬†

‚ÄúI just think people can have things on their body that they might never have had a chance to try,‚Äù Parker explains, adding: ‚ÄúIt feels like it‚Äôs a nice way for people to have some more assurance and also a touch of fantasy.‚Äù

So, if you‚Äôre needing some festive outfit inspo and fantasy (from the comfort of your couch), consider it sorted.

title: Andra Day Says Bradley Cooper ‚ÄúBacked Up His Support‚Äù By Casting Her As His Wife In Is This Thing On?
text:
Andra Day Says Bradley Cooper ‚ÄúBacked Up His Support‚Äù By Casting Her As His Wife In Is This Thing On?

Is This Thing On? may not seem like a movie where you‚Äôd find Grammy-award winner and Oscar nominee Andra Day. It‚Äôs about a white man doing stand-up comedy after all. But the Bradley Cooper-directed divorce dramedy starring Will Arnett and Laura Dern wouldn‚Äôt be complete without Day, who brings some brutal honesty and a delightful groundedness to the film. She plays Christine, the best friend to Dern‚Äôs Tess, and the wife of Cooper‚Äôs Balls (yes, that‚Äôs really his character‚Äôs name). Tess is going through a divorce with Arnett‚Äôs Alex, who turns to stand-up comedy to cope with their breakup. Day is so good as Christine in every scene, it feels like you‚Äôre eavesdropping on old friends who can‚Äôt help but tell each other the truth ‚Äî no matter how uncomfortable.¬†

Cooper handpicked Day for the role and was sure she‚Äôd say no. ‚ÄúI was just crossing my fingers with Andra,‚Äù Cooper says in the film‚Äôs production notes. ‚ÄúI just knew she would say no, but I had to offer it to her. When I saw The United States vs. Billie Holliday, I was floored. I was like, ‚ÄòLook, I apologize that the real estate is going to be small here, but here is the terrain. Would you please come do this with me?‚Äô It was a huge coup to get her.‚Äù And with the small real estate Day is given, she builds a brick house. It‚Äôs a no-bullshit performance that leaps off the screen, leaving the audience wanting more of Christine. And the dynamic between her and Tess ‚Äúmakes for a delicious, spiky friendship,‚Äù Dern says.¬†

Here, Day talks about Cooper‚Äôs support, building rapport with Dern, singing with Sean Hayes, and why she‚Äôd never get back together with an ex.

Refinery29 Unbothered: I loved the film and was surprised by how much I was moved by it! I know that Bradley Cooper said he had to convince you, or that when he asked you to do this, he didn‚Äôt think you would say yes.¬†

Andra Day: Is this what he‚Äôs telling people? [laughs] He did not have to convince me of anything! He just popped on the screen and he was Bradley Cooper and I was like, ‚Äúgreat idea, let‚Äôs work together!‚Äù He‚Äôs so funny. I genuinely was very excited to be a part of [this movie]. I‚Äôm a huge fan of his work as an actor. I‚Äôm a huge fan of his work as a director. I just think he‚Äôs just shown he‚Äôs just such a brilliant director. He‚Äôs just a great filmmaker. So I was excited. I was like, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm actually looking forward to being in your hands and seeing what you put together with this cast.‚Äù I‚Äôm so glad you love the movie. And maybe I‚Äôm biased, but I love the movie too.

Tell me more about why you chose to take on this role.

AD: I was really moved by [Bradley Cooper‚Äôs] support. I also knew that he was really supportive of two other movies I had done. So for him to back up that support with the offer to play this character, I thought was really, really special. And then he starts describing the movie to me. It‚Äôs Will Arnett‚Äôs baby, and they‚Äôve been friends for such a long time. So I love that it was he [cast] himself as [the character] Balls, because who else better to play Will‚Äôs best friend than his actual best friend? I love the dynamic of the friend group. I love the themes of truth, of rediscovery, of transformation, and communication, and just growth. I think it‚Äôs so funny. We always talk about growth, but we never allow each other to change. So I love that the movie dealt with all of those themes. And then Bradley mentioned the names Will Arnett, Laura Dern and Sean Hayes. And I was like, this is all just getting too crazy. They are all just so great. It was a dream cast to work with and it was exactly what I thought it would be. And better.

I love what you just said: ‚Äúwe always talk about growth, but we don‚Äôt allow each other to change.‚Äù That was a bar!¬†

AD: You know, maybe I was a little rapper in my past life [laughs]. Nah, I‚Äôm just kidding but I think it‚Äôs true!¬†

I want to talk about that cast that you mentioned, because there are some heavy hitters. You play Laura Dern‚Äôs best friend, Christine. Talk about building that rapport with Laura Dern, because it does feel like you‚Äôre just dropped into this years-long friendship. How did you build that rapport?

AD: It‚Äôs amazing to feel like you were just dropped in this relationship. I think that‚Äôs a testament to the great writing, the great direction and how it was shot, but also the truth.¬† Bradley absolutely requires truth. That‚Äôs the thing we‚Äôre looking for. But working with Laura, first of all, I‚Äôm just such a huge fan of her work. Laura plays such an array of characters, and so, of course, you walk into her space and you‚Äôre intimidated at first. You got to make sure you show up and support and you‚Äôre present but beyond that, being able to work with Laura and discovering, oh, wow, she is amazing. She‚Äôs great at what she does, and a huge part of that is how generous she is on set, how generous she is with not just the director and her co stars, but everyone on set, every actor, personnel on set and and how honest and open she is about herself as a human, and how much of that she brings to the character.¬†

Christine is such a protective friend.

AD: I love that you see that! [laughs]¬†

She‚Äôs like, don‚Äôt mess with my girl! How protective of a friend are you? Could you relate to that in Christine?

AD: No, I have ADHD, so I can‚Äôt focus on shit. Most of the time I don‚Äôt even remember. [laughs] I‚Äôm just kidding! No,I think I am a protective friend. [gestures off camera]. Look, I have a friend in the room that‚Äôs nodding her head ‚Äúyes‚Äù and laughing right now.

I think I am definitely a protective friend, for sure. What I like about Christine, though, is that she is a protective friend, but she will also protect you from yourself. I think that what I love about her character is her brutal honesty. I think what makes it so not just digestible, but actually endearing, is the fact that she is equally as brutally honest with herself. That‚Äôs really the only way to be honest with someone, that‚Äôs the only way they can actually trust your advice or your critique, if that they know that you hold yourself to that same standard. I think we‚Äôre similar in that way. I can be very protective, and not just physically, but also emotionally when it comes to friends and people that I love.

Stand-up comedy is the beating heart throughout this film. Is stand-up something you‚Äôve ever thought about doing? Did this movie change your opinion of it at all?¬†

AD: Stand-up comedy is never something I ever thought about doing, and still have never thought about doing because it looks terrifying to me. You know what‚Äôs funny, I was saying¬† about the movie that it makes me laugh when we describe John Bishop [who inspired] Will Arnett‚Äôs character, Alex Novak, and they‚Äôre like, ‚ÄúYeah, he just kind of did this stand-up because he didn‚Äôt want to pay the cover.‚Äù And I‚Äôm like, ‚Äúguys, that‚Äôs not normal.‚Äù [laughs]. Like, if it were me, and someone was like, you can either pay the cover or you can go do stand up. I‚Äôm either coming out of my pocket 15 bucks or I‚Äôm going to the restaurant down the street. I‚Äôm not going to do a set of stand-up for $15!¬† It‚Äôs too terrifying.¬†

I think it takes something inherently in you to do that. But what I learned was about the community of stand-up. I think it‚Äôs an incredible community. Bradley [Cooper] has always loved stand-up. And I think we all have, right? The Richard Pryors, Eddie Murphys. But the connectedness and the camaraderie were amazing to me. It used to be a lot more competitive. Now, when you dip into the culture, you realize that they‚Äôre doing, like, 3 to 6, clubs a night, which is insane. The grind is such that I‚Äôve always admired stand-up comics, I loved to see how connected they are. And I think that Bradley [Cooper] and Will [Arnett] did an incredible job of showing this community, how they support each other, how they joke, and how honest they are as people.

There‚Äôs this incredible scene where you and Sean Hayes sing ‚ÄúAmazing Grace.‚Äù How did that come to be?

AD: First, I love singing with Sean. I love Sean‚Äôs voice. Twas an amazing scene to shoot. It was amazing because it wasn‚Äôt written in the script. The night before, I got a call from Bradley that was like, ‚ÄúWhat do you think about singing ‚ÄòAmazing Grace‚Äô?‚Äù I was like, ‚ÄúSure!‚Äù That was one of the later scenes we shot and I was, I was used to us being on set and being able to pivot. Who knows if it would be amazing or if it‚Äôd be really cringe and weird? I didn‚Äôt know. But it worked.

That scene, for me, and a lot of the Oyster Bay scenes, helped me to feel much more a part of this group. It just felt like we just were enjoying each other‚Äôs presence while we were on set filming that scene. And then I think it translated for the audience ‚Äî them singing Amazing Grace added like, 10 or 15 years to their friendship.¬†

We‚Äôre going to end on a little game. I‚Äôm going to give you scenarios ‚Äî based on the movie ‚Äî and the answers are either ‚ÄúBothered or Unbothered.‚Äù Your partner decides to become a stand up comedian later in life, bothered or unbothered?¬†

AD: Unbothered! I‚Äôm an artist in that way. I‚Äôm just kind of like, ‚Äúyou‚Äôre fine. Try it if you love it!‚Äù

You don‚Äôt like your best friend‚Äôs husband: bothered or unbothered?

AD: Super bothered! Super duper bothered!¬†

Telling your best friend‚Äôs man you used to have a crush on him.

AD: Oohh. This is where I differ from my character. I‚Äôm a little more bothered about that.

Getting back together with an ex.

AD: Bothered, bothered, bothered! You an ex for a reason.

Your friend doesn‚Äôt tell you she got back together with her ex. Bothered or unbothered?

AD: Bothered. Not because you got back with your ex ‚Äî unless he‚Äôs a toxic ex ‚Äî I‚Äôm like, sis, what are we doing? Bothered, because if he‚Äôs a decent person, then what am I doing that made you feel uncomfortable to talk to me about that? If we‚Äôre best friends and I‚Äôm a confidant, then I‚Äôm bothered a little bit with myself and the situation.

When people announce their breakup on social media or publicly.

AD: I don‚Äôt care. Unbothered. I‚Äôm like, do you! Who cares?

Finally, using your personal life as fodder for art or comedy, bothered or unbothered?

AD: Unbothered, that‚Äôs actually art and comedy. I‚Äôm bothered when you don‚Äôt use it at all. You know what I‚Äôm saying? That‚Äôs when I‚Äôm bothered.

Is This Thing On? is in theaters Friday, December 19.¬†

title: The Final New Moon Of 2025 Will Bring A Major Shake Up
text:
The Final New Moon Of 2025 Will Bring A Major Shake Up

In true form, the New Moon in Sagittarius on December 19th is going to be a wild roller coaster of emotions. It‚Äôs officially the last new moon of 2025 and it‚Äôs going to bring high energy and a truly uplifting lunar reset.

But just when we thought we had escaped confusing and ambiguous times brought on by a season of five planetary retrogrades, the New Moon in Sagittarius arrives and shakes up our emotions and relationships ‚Äî¬†once again. Venus in Sagittarius, Saturn in Pisces, and Neptune in Pisces aspect the New Moon, creating a mixed bag of emotions. Venus‚Äô alignment gives us hope to enhance our love lives, while Saturn limits and Neptune heightens our fantasies ‚Äî so, we may feel as though we are stuck in a situationship that‚Äôs holding us back, but have faith that things will get better soon. Add in a minor frustration from Jupiter retrograde in Cancer and Uranus retrograde in Taurus, and the vibe gets both saucy and sassy.¬†

As a result, our intuition will prove to be powerful. It‚Äôll be easier than ever for us to comprehend matters on a spiritual level. The flip side is that we might also be paranoid or delulu in certain matters. Finding a balance between embracing our instincts and logic is pivotal to ensure we don‚Äôt go overboard in one direction over another. It‚Äôll be challenging to remain centered, which is why grounding exercises such as connecting to the body through yoga or a walk in nature will do us good. This activity will clear our minds and remind us to remain present ‚Äî no matter what the universe throws our way.

The need for change is strong, as we yearn to evolve in our love lives. The lessons Saturn imparts on us are going to rock our worlds for the better. The fog brought on by Neptune might hold us captive, but it will dissipate soon. Trusting our hearts and others unthinkingly can lead us to question what we want and whether we are making the best choices, but we‚Äôll see that our innate divine wisdom and knowledge hold the key to our happiness. Ignoring outside noise and opinions of others helps guide us to the right space and place. Venus and the New Moon push us to roll the dice and bet on our feelings. We have to ‚Äúknow when to hold ‚Äòem and when to fold ‚Äòem.‚Äù

The following day, Mercury in Sagittarius squares the Nodes of Destiny on the Pisces and Virgo lunar axis. It‚Äôll be hard to find the best way to move forward without drama or arguments, since we are bewildered about what the best path is. The mutable T-Square is causing our nerves to heighten. Our anxieties might reach a fever pitch as we continue to ruminate over the avenue we wish to pursue. Before getting into a headspin and over matters, take a step back and contemplate through meditation. If we are lucky, the universe will grant us both clarity and self-discovery.

In moments like this, it‚Äôs always great to reflect and take stock of our desires and progress. The Temperance tarot card (which aligns with the sun sign Sagittarius) represents this sentiment, since it focuses on how we can find our calm in turbulent times. Patience ignites the dream to come alive. Therefore, we shouldn‚Äôt make impetuous decisions. Moderation is essential to finding our deepest feelings, motives, and passions. Even though we are caught in the middle of the storm, we can navigate it. The only way out is through ‚Äî we won‚Äôt realize it immediately, but we are in the driver‚Äôs seat. Let your senses and heart be the map that you listen to.

title: 12 Fresh Bob Haircut Trends You‚Äôre Going To See Everywhere In 2026
text:
12 Fresh Bob Haircut Trends You‚Äôre Going To See Everywhere In 2026

When it comes to haircut trends, the choice is overwhelming, but if we had to crown one cut as the current style du jour, it would be the bob.¬†

Its versatility is what gives the bob an edge over other cuts. Want to go really short? Consider the bixie, aka bob-meets-pixie. Worried about losing too much length? Try the lob, or long bob. And that‚Äôs just the tip of the iceberg, because hairstylists from London to Los Angeles are dreaming up new iterations of the cut daily ‚Äî and we predict that, in 2026, there‚Äôll be no escaping the temptation to brave the scissors.

With that in mind, scroll ahead for the bob haircut trends top stylists predict will reign supreme in 2026 and beyond.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Korean Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Timothy Ting (@timothyting_hove)

Hairstylist George Curran bills the Korean bob as one of the most exciting haircut innovations. ‚ÄúThe cut is designed so you can have a bob when your hair is tied or clipped up, and long hair when it‚Äôs worn down,‚Äù says Curren. It‚Äôs literally two hairstyles in one. ‚ÄúNo extensions and all without committing to losing your length,‚Äù adds Curran. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a clever optical illusion haircut using a specialist Korean cutting technique, and it‚Äôs perfect for anyone who wants versatility without compromise.‚Äù This video posted to Instagram by Timothy Ting is mesmerizing.

The Airy Bixie

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Jordz (@boyjordz.hair)

‚ÄúThis blends charm and delicacy with a modern and lived-in edge,‚Äù says Devin Graciano is a professional hairstylist and CEO of Goldie Locks. She adds, ‚ÄúThe style is lightweight, soft, and full of movement, which gives it that effortless, airy feel,‚Äù ‚Äî but it boasts attitude and intention, too. ‚ÄúThe bixie complements the playful and confident person who wears it,‚Äù says Graciano. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a cut that feels both current and timeless, with room for personalization depending on texture and personality.‚Äù This cut by Jordz is perfect.¬†

The Blunt Curly Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Nadine Koca | Fashion & Hair (@nadinekoca)

Curly hair specialist Dusty Schlabach predicts that the blunt curly bob will be everywhere. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a zero-layer, ultra-clean blunt bob that sits right at the chin,‚Äù says Schlabach, adding, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs perfect for medium to low-density curls because it keeps the shape sleek without stacking or creating that Christmas tree effect at the baseline‚Äù ‚Äî no triangular shapes here. Instead, the silhouette is ‚Äúintentional,‚Äù says Schlabach, who suggests asking your stylist to cut your curls dry, exactly in their natural pattern. ‚ÄúThink a straight-across blunt line and no layers ‚Äî just the slightest, almost invisible A-line so it sits clean at the chin,‚Äù says Schlabach. This cut on Nadine Koca is beautiful.

The Shattered Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Pam Mlunjwana (@pammacb)

Rather than a clean, blunt line, the ends of the shattered bob are point-cut or ‚Äúshattered‚Äù by slicing into the hair vertically to create a ‚Äúchoppy, airy, slightly fragmented finish,‚Äù says Curran, like this look on Pam Mlunjwana. ‚ÄúIt has that effortless, undone vibe,‚Äù he continues. But make no mistake: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a very technical cut that relies on precision and the right styling products.‚Äù Layering is essential to add movement, says Curran. ‚ÄúYou want the hair to have body and flow, without slipping into that helmet-like shape. I remove a lot of weight through the layers, particularly around the [back], which gives the cut bounce and stops it feeling heavy or bulky.‚Äù

Curran says the shattered bob looks best when it‚Äôs relaxed and a little tousled. ‚ÄúThat cool-girl, lived-in texture feels intentional but never overdone. A product like Tecni Art Pli works really well, and finishing with Techni Art Volume Dust.‚Äù

The Bangless French Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Faick Zekai (@faick_hair)

When Curran thinks of a French bob, the words classic, timeless, and iconic spring to his mind. ‚ÄúIn 2025, we saw this style evolve with softer layering around the face,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúBut as we head into 2026, it‚Äôs all about a more grown-out, effortless version of the look,‚Äù like this one by Faick Zekai. According to Curran, it stays sophisticated thanks to a strong, heavy finish through the ends and very minimal layering throughout.

The Liquid Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by TAMPA HAIRSTYLIST (@sophie.coastalhair)

Coined by Graciano, the liquid bob is a ‚Äúsleek, softly sculpted bob with seamless layers and polished ends that move like fluid.‚Äù It‚Äôs glossy, weightless, and intentionally refined, she adds. Simply ask your stylist for a ‚Äúblunt-to-soft perimeter bob,‚Äù advises Graciano, complete with subtle internal layering. ‚ÄúWearing it blow-dried smooth emphasizes shine and swing,‚Äù says Graciano. This cut by Tampa hairstylist Sophie is stunning.

The Bubble Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Yasmeen Ÿäÿßÿ≥ŸÖŸäŸÜ (@yasmeenscott)

The bubble bob ‚Äî aka rounded layered curly bob, according to Schlabach ‚Äî is the total opposite of the aforementioned blunt bob. ‚ÄúThis cut uses soft, intentional layers to create a rounder, more lifted shape that distributes weight evenly,‚Äù says Schlabach. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs ideal for dense curls that tend to build bulk at the bottom because the layers prevent heaviness and open up movement throughout the shape.‚Äù

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Ashlynn Rudzinski (@arud_)

It looks just as great on straight and wavy hair, as shown by Ashlynn Rudzinski here. So what should you ask for? ‚ÄúA rounded bob with intentional layering to release weight and build shape ‚Äî cut dry so the layers match the natural curl pattern and keep the silhouette lifted,‚Äù says Schlabach. We love this look on Yasmeen Scott.

The Cowgirl Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by miho mai / Á¶èÂ≤°„Éú„Éñ / „Éú„Éñ / „Éú„Éñ„Éë„Éº„Éû / Á¶èÂ≤°ÁæéÂÆπÂÆ§ / „Éä„ÉÅ„É•„É©„É´ (@zoey__mai)

The cowgirl bob has a strong ‚Äô90s influence, says Curran. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs going to be a big evolution from the French bob or the blunt, one-length, ultra-polished look √† la Sofia Richie-Grainge,‚Äù he adds. The cowgirl bob has a few defining attributes: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs softer, shaggier, and more relaxed ‚Äî for those who don‚Äôt want a super-sleek finish and prefer a bit more movement and natural texture.‚Äù Curran points to Alexa Chung as inspiration. ‚ÄúWhat I love most is how bespoke you can make it,‚Äù adds Curran. ‚ÄúYou can tailor it completely to the client and frame the face with soft or grown-out bangs.‚Äù

To style it, Curran recommends using a curling iron to create a subtle kick through the ends. ‚ÄúThis will enhance that relaxed, cowgirl-inspired movement,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI always finish with L‚ÄôOr√©al Professionnel Tecni Art Volume Panache to keep the texture airy and full of body. You want it to look deliberately imperfect.‚Äù Miho Mai gets it so right here.

The Soft Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Faick Zekai (@faick_hair)

This is a rounded, gently layered bob, which Graciano says is designed to enhance natural texture. ‚ÄúIt keeps the shape airy and controlled, never bulky,‚Äù she says ‚Äî just like this cut by Faick Zekai. ‚ÄúAsk your stylist for a bob that hits between the jaw and collarbone, with light internal layering and curl-by-curl shaping to maintain softness and movement.‚Äù

The Asymmetric Pixie Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Sheridan Holyoak (@shmoakin_hair)

Brace yourselves: the pob, aka the pixie bob, is making a comeback ‚Äî and Curran predicts it‚Äôll be one of the standout cuts of 2026. ‚ÄúThink Scarlett Johansson circa 2015 or Victoria Beckham in her 2007 Posh bob era,‚Äù says Curran. He adds, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre seeing a real shift towards shapes that feel more architectural yet still wearable, and this cut ticks every box. I love the contrast it creates: one side sharp and cropped, the other slightly longer, sweeping, and sculpted.‚Äù Even better, Curran says it‚Äôs the ideal next step for anyone with a ‚Äô90s bob who wants to go shorter. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs bold, low-maintenance, and super stylish.‚Äù We adore this cut by Sheridan Holyoak.¬†

The Curly Lob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Jessenia Robayo (@jesseniaspallet)

Schlabach says that the curly lob, or long bob, is a slightly longer version of the bubble and blunt curly bobs. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a shoulder-grazing cut that keeps length while maintaining structure,‚Äù adds Schlabach, ‚Äúand it‚Äôs often paired with thoughtful face-framing or a soft veil bang to open up the front and create natural movement.‚Äù Thanks to the additional few inches, this style works well across most curl types and densities, says Schlabach. Remember to request some movement around the face to give it dimension, like this cut by Jessenia Robayo.

The Layered Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by miho mai / Á¶èÂ≤°„Éú„Éñ / „Éú„Éñ / „Éú„Éñ„Éë„Éº„Éû / Á¶èÂ≤°ÁæéÂÆπÂÆ§ / „Éä„ÉÅ„É•„É©„É´ (@zoey__mai)

Curran says the layered bob was one of the most-liked bob haircuts on TikTok last month. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a longer, ‚Äô90s-inspired style with layers at the front and throughout,‚Äù much like this cut by Miho Mai. The slightly wet-look texture emphasizes the choppiness of the layers, giving it a modern feel, while the lash-grazing full fringe brings in a touch of retro balance.
